data.title: Implemented locking the cursor into the window for the Windows platform
data.body:
I exposed the ability to restrict the mouse to the window.

On a somewhat related note I ended up doing this by running into some difference between MonoGame and XNA. If you have a windowed game and your cursor leaves the window it stops updating its relative coordinates.

Mouse state behaves different in MonoGame than XNA 4. I quickly checked that XNA it will happily provide you with relative coordinates that track your cursor outside of the window.  After digging through the source I believe this is because of WinFormsGameForm's method of handling mouse events. The events delegated through the Form's control's event handlers.  This leads to MouseMove not firing when the mouse is not over the control.

[WinFormsGameWindow.cs](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Windows/WinFormsGameWindow.cs#L184)

This could be solved by updating the [Mouse.GetState](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Input/Mouse.cs#L128) to grab the real mouse location and translate it back into the relative position. 

I'll happily go create a separate feature branch to tackle that. Regardless being able to leverage the Form's cursor clip logic directly is heavily preferable than readjust the cursor back in bounds with a update loop's worth of delay.

data.title: Added initialization check for iOS Guide
data.body:
I added an initialization check in iOS's `Guide.Initialise` to make sure that calling Guide.Initialise a second time is safe. As [discussed here](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2512), iOS is handling how/when the Guide gets initialized a bit differently than the other platforms, and although it only seems to get called for once right now, it seems prudent to make sure that the call to Initialise is a bit safer in case that ever changes.

Note: GitHub's diff on this file seems to be freaking out a bit (20 additions!), but really all that's changed is there's a `if (!_isInitialised)` check around the initialization code block.

data.title: Content compression support
data.body:
Adds support for content compression using LZMA from the 7-Zip SDK that handily comes with a C# version.

LZMA content compression is flagged using one of the unused bits in the flags field (0x40).  The flag for XNA's LZX compression remains unchanged.

Added a /compress option to MGCB along with documentation in mgcb.md.

A sample 1024x768 texture using SurfaceFormat.Color is 3073KB uncompressed and 1006KB compressed.  It took 6.4 seconds to build and compress the asset.  The compressed texture loaded in 0.423s (in WindowsGL test project) while the uncompressed texture loaded in 0.011s, so on desktop platforms.  On Android (Nexus 5), the compressed asset loaded in 1.422s and the uncompressed asset loaded in 0.072s.

The 7-Zip SDK is split between MonoGame.Framework and MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline.  Decoding and common classes are in MonoGame.Framework and encoding classes are in MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline.

We could also try compiling and using the C version of the 7-Zip SDK to see what improvement it gives to encoding and decoding performance.

Color.Lerp does a Clamp on the weight between 0 and 1. The overflow and

data.title: Android Context Lost Fix
data.body:
Currently the code in the AndroidGameView assumes the GL Context is lost when the app is paused and resumed. So it always calls a DeviceReset  and attempts to load the assets again. With the latest Xamarin.Android the bug that caused this issue is fixed. Two new methods have been introduced OnContextLost OnContextSet. 

OnContextLost is only called if the GL context is actually broken, when this method is called the context is dead completely. 

OnContextSet is only called when a context is created, this occurs on startup and only after the Context is actually lost. It is at this point what a valid context is available for loading textures and shaders. the normal Loaded method is called after this one.  

These changes set the Resuming flag in the OnContextLost method so we can reload the assets on startup. This will happen very rarely since the original bug where the context was lost when a app was paused is fixed in the Xamarin.Android OpenTK 0.9.9.3 and 1.0.0.0. With this fix android apps should resume without the need to reload textures or shaders.

data.body: Create a `Sound` and add several `Wave`s to it. This will create `Track`s for that `Sound` that play at the same time when the Sound is played. This fails in MonoGame with a `NotSupportedException`.

data.title: Instance Limiting is ignored for Cues in XACT
data.body:
The default behavior in XNA is that the number of times a Cue can be played simultaneous is not limited. In MonoGame however the limit is just 1, the default behavior being to immediately stop the previously playing cue without a crossfade.

Setting `Limit Instances` and related options `Behavior At Max`, `Replace Intance` and `Crossfade Type` have no effect on the instance limiting.

Note that `Instance Limiting` can be set on individual Cues, but also at the `Categories` level.

data.title: SoundBank does not support Pitch Variation
data.body:
Calling PlayCue or GetCue on SoundBank will result in a NotSupportedException when the Cue has Pitch Var. enabled (Pitch Variation).

Additional information: Specified method is not supported.

data.title: Android fast app resume
data.body:
This PR implements Android Fast App Resume. This means that we greatly reduce how often we need to restore content (textures/shaders) from disk when we are backgrounded and reopened.

This relied on a [fix recently added to Xamarin.](http://forums.xamarin.com/discussion/comment/52186/#Comment_52186)

We also state we support ScreenSize changes as this apparently improves the chances that this is successful (see end of [this comment](http://forums.xamarin.com/discussion/comment/60864/#Comment_60864))

I have tested on android 2.3.4 (Xperia Play) and 4.4.2 (HP Touchpad Cyanogen mod) using the Platformer2D sample, reopening the app is basically instant now! :)

Fixes #2600

Edit: If the build fails on the build bot, it may need its Xamarin.Android updating to at least 4.12.3.

data.title: openal-soft implementation for Android
data.body:
Uses the same OpenAL code as most other supported MonoGame platforms.
Supports low latency sound on Android v4.2 and above.  Devices lower than v4.2 will have higher latency on sound playback.  Android v4.4 and higher no longer require double-buffered sound on the application side.  Tested on Nexus S with v4.1.2 and Nexus 5 with v4.4.4.
Target framework version raised to v4.2 (API Level 17) in Android and Ouya projects to allow testing for low latency sound support.  Application projects should have "Compile using Android version" set to API Level 17, "Minimum Android to target" set to API Level 14 and "Target Android version" set to "Use Compile using SDK version".  This allows use of the functions to test low latency sound support (available in v4.2), but apps can still be run on v4.0 devices.
GenerateProject.xslt extracted from Protobuild.exe to allow target framework version to be changed in Android and Ouya projects and to add support for EmbeddedNativeLibrary items.
